title: Best Glean AI Search Alternatives in 2025: Top 10 Tools Compared
metaDescription: Looking for Glean AI Search alternatives? Compare top 10 enterprise search, vector database, and AI research tools like Milvus, Semantic Scholar, Elastic, and Vectara for your needs.
introduction:
Glean AI Search has established itself as a powerful enterprise solution for unifying knowledge discovery across applications like Google Workspace, Microsoft 365, and Slack. Its strength lies in solving the 'findability' problem through deep organizational context and strict access governance. However, organizations seek alternatives for various reasons, including cost considerations, specific technical requirements, or different use cases beyond traditional enterprise search.

Some teams require specialized tools for academic research, where Glean's enterprise focus may not provide the depth needed for scientific literature analysis. Developers building custom AI applications often need foundational components like vector databases rather than complete platforms. Other organizations might prioritize open-source solutions for greater control and customization, or seek more affordable entry points than Glean's enterprise-only pricing model.

The landscape of AI-powered search and knowledge discovery has expanded dramatically, with tools now specializing in everything from vector similarity search to research synthesis. This guide explores the top alternatives across different categories, helping you identify the right solution whether you're building custom AI infrastructure, conducting academic research, or seeking enterprise search capabilities with different technical approaches.

mainPlatformAnalysis.overview: Glean AI Search is a comprehensive enterprise platform that connects to and indexes data from a company's entire application ecosystem (Google Workspace, Microsoft 365, Slack, Salesforce, Jira, etc.). It uses natural language processing to understand user intent and provide contextual answers with citations while enforcing strict access controls. The platform uniquely builds understanding of organizational relationships and content relevance beyond simple keyword matching.
limitations: Enterprise-only pricing with no transparent public pricing
Primarily focused on workplace applications rather than specialized domains like academic research
Less suitable for developers needing low-level vector search infrastructure components
mainPlatformAnalysis.pricing: Glean operates on an enterprise pricing model with custom quotes based on organization size, number of users, and required integrations. There is no publicly available pricing tier, and interested organizations must contact sales for a demonstration and quote. Implementation typically involves professional services for deployment and configuration.
mainPlatformAnalysis.bestFor: Large enterprises needing a unified search solution across their entire suite of workplace applications with strict security and access governance requirements.

alternatives.name: Milvus
alternatives.tagline: Open-source vector database for massive-scale similarity search
alternatives.description: Milvus is an open-source vector database specifically designed to store, index, and manage massive embedding vectors generated by deep neural networks and machine learning models. Its cloud-native, distributed architecture separates storage and compute, enabling petabyte-scale similarity search and analytics on unstructured data with high performance and low latency. Unlike Glean's complete enterprise search platform, Milvus serves as a foundational infrastructure component for developers building custom AI applications like semantic search, recommendation systems, and AI services that require efficient vector operations at scale.
alternatives.pricing: Open-source (Apache 2.0 license) with commercial support and managed cloud services available
alternatives.bestFor: Developers and enterprises building large-scale AI applications requiring high-performance vector similarity search infrastructure.
keyFeatures: Support for multiple index types and metrics
cons: Requires significant technical expertise to deploy and manage
Not a complete search platform like Glean
Primarily focused on vector operations rather than document processing
alternatives.whySwitch: Choose Milvus over Glean if you need a foundational vector database component for building custom AI applications rather than a complete enterprise search platform, or if you require open-source infrastructure with maximum scalability for similarity search operations.

alternatives.name: Semantic Scholar
alternatives.tagline: AI-powered research tool for scientific literature discovery
alternatives.description: Semantic Scholar is an AI-powered research tool developed by the Allen Institute for AI that helps scholars discover and understand scientific literature through machine learning. It extracts key insights from millions of academic papers, providing TL;DR summaries, citation graphs, and field-specific author profiles. Unlike Glean's enterprise workplace focus, Semantic Scholar specializes exclusively in academic research, offering deep semantic understanding of scientific concepts and relationships across disciplines. Its free accessibility makes it particularly valuable for students, researchers, and professionals navigating vast scientific literature.
alternatives.pricing: Completely free with no premium tiers
alternatives.bestFor: Academic researchers, students, and professionals who need to efficiently navigate and understand scientific literature.
pros: Completely free with no usage limits
Specialized for academic research with deep domain understanding
Developed by reputable AI research institute
Regular updates with new papers and features
cons: Limited to academic/scientific content only
No enterprise deployment or customization options
Less suitable for general workplace search needs
alternatives.whySwitch: Choose Semantic Scholar over Glean if your primary need is academic research rather than enterprise workplace search, or if you require specialized tools for scientific literature analysis with citation tracking and paper summarization.

alternatives.name: Annoy
alternatives.tagline: Spotify's efficient approximate nearest neighbor search library
alternatives.description: Annoy (Approximate Nearest Neighbors Oh Yeah) is a C++ library with Python bindings developed by Spotify for performing fast, memory-efficient approximate nearest neighbor searches in high-dimensional spaces. It builds large, static read-only tree-based indices that are memory-mapped, enabling multiple processes to share the same data for rapid queries. Unlike Glean's comprehensive enterprise platform, Annoy is a lightweight library optimized for production environments where low memory footprint and high query speed are critical, making it ideal for building recommendation systems and similarity search backends as part of larger applications.
alternatives.bestFor: Developers building production recommendation systems or similarity search features requiring efficient ANN operations.
pros: Fast query performance for static datasets
cons: Only supports static indices (no real-time updates)
Limited to approximate nearest neighbor search only
Requires rebuilding index for data updates
alternatives.whySwitch: Choose Annoy over Glean if you need a lightweight, efficient library for approximate nearest neighbor search as part of a custom application, particularly for static datasets where memory efficiency and query speed are paramount.

alternatives.name: Consensus
alternatives.tagline: AI search engine for evidence-based research answers
alternatives.description: Consensus is an AI-powered search engine specifically designed for scientific research that uses large language models to read, extract, and synthesize findings directly from peer-reviewed academic papers. Users can ask research questions in plain English and receive evidence-based answers with citations, with the platform uniquely focusing on providing consensus-level insights by analyzing multiple studies. Unlike Glean's enterprise workplace orientation, Consensus specializes in helping students, researchers, and professionals quickly understand scientific landscapes and identify research consensus across thousands of papers.
alternatives.pricing: Freemium model with free tier and premium subscriptions for advanced features
alternatives.bestFor: Students, researchers, and professionals needing to quickly understand scientific consensus and evidence on specific topics.
pros: Provides consensus-level insights not just individual papers
Regular database updates with new research
cons: Limited to academic/scientific content
Less comprehensive than full literature review tools
Premium features required for advanced usage
alternatives.whySwitch: Choose Consensus over Glean if your primary need is understanding scientific evidence and consensus rather than searching workplace documents, or if you need quick, evidence-based answers to research questions with proper citations.

alternatives.name: Elastic Semantic Search
alternatives.tagline: Vector search integrated into the mature Elastic ecosystem
alternatives.description: Elastic Semantic Search is a vector search and retrieval platform integrated into the Elastic Stack that enables AI-powered, context-aware search beyond traditional keyword matching. It uses machine learning models to generate and query vector embeddings, allowing semantic similarity search, conversational AI enhancement, and enterprise search with natural language understanding. Unlike Glean's standalone platform, Elastic Semantic Search benefits from deep integration with the mature, scalable Elasticsearch ecosystem, offering hybrid search capabilities that combine traditional BM25 with modern kNN vector search within a widely-adopted enterprise search and observability platform.
alternatives.pricing: Paid subscription model with various tiers based on features and scale
alternatives.bestFor: Enterprises already using or considering Elastic Stack who need integrated vector search capabilities.
keyFeatures: Hybrid search combining BM25 and vector kNN
pros: Integrates with mature Elastic Stack ecosystem
Hybrid search capabilities for best of both worlds
cons: Can be complex to configure optimally
Requires Elasticsearch infrastructure knowledge
Cost can scale significantly with data volume
alternatives.whySwitch: Choose Elastic Semantic Search over Glean if you're already invested in the Elastic ecosystem or need hybrid search capabilities combining traditional and vector approaches within a mature enterprise search platform.

alternatives.name: Qdrant
alternatives.tagline: High-performance vector database written in Rust
alternatives.description: Qdrant is a high-performance, open-source vector database and similarity search engine designed for production-scale AI applications, written in Rust for optimal speed and memory efficiency. It enables efficient storage, retrieval, and management of vector embeddings with advanced filtering capabilities, making it ideal for building semantic search, recommendation systems, and RAG pipelines. Unlike Glean's complete enterprise search solution, Qdrant focuses specifically on vector operations with strong consistency guarantees and offers both cloud-managed and self-hosted deployment options for developers building custom AI applications.
alternatives.pricing: Freemium model with open-source version and paid cloud services
alternatives.bestFor: Developers building production AI applications requiring high-performance vector search with filtering capabilities.
keyFeatures: Written in Rust for speed and memory efficiency
pros: Excellent performance due to Rust implementation
Advanced filtering capabilities for complex queries
cons: Smaller ecosystem than some alternatives
Primarily focused on vector operations only
Requires technical expertise for optimal use
alternatives.whySwitch: Choose Qdrant over Glean if you need a high-performance vector database with advanced filtering capabilities for building custom AI applications, particularly if performance and memory efficiency are critical requirements.

alternatives.name: Elicit
alternatives.tagline: AI research assistant for literature review automation
alternatives.description: Elicit is an AI research assistant designed to automate and accelerate the academic literature review process by using language models to find, summarize, and extract specific data from millions of academic papers. It helps researchers answer questions based on existing studies through semantic understanding of research concepts rather than just keyword matching, significantly reducing manual screening time. Unlike Glean's enterprise workplace focus, Elicit specializes in academic research with curated databases and tools specifically designed for literature review, data extraction, and evidence-based research synthesis.
alternatives.pricing: Freemium model with free tier and paid plans for advanced features
alternatives.bestFor: Researchers and academics needing to accelerate literature review and data extraction from scientific papers.
pros: Good semantic understanding of research concepts
Regular improvements based on user feedback
cons: Limited to academic research domain
Database coverage may have gaps in some fields
Advanced features require paid subscription
alternatives.whySwitch: Choose Elicit over Glean if your primary need is academic literature review automation rather than enterprise workplace search, or if you need specialized tools for extracting specific data from research papers.

alternatives.name: SciSpace
alternatives.tagline: AI research assistant for reading and understanding complex papers
alternatives.description: SciSpace (formerly Typeset) is an AI-powered research assistant that helps users discover, read, and understand scientific literature through semantic search, interactive AI explanations, and citation analysis. Its core capabilities include explaining complex papers in simple language, summarizing research, and answering specific questions about uploaded PDFs, combining multiple approaches to accelerate literature review. Unlike Glean's enterprise orientation, SciSpace focuses specifically on helping students, researchers, and professionals overcome comprehension barriers when dealing with complex scientific papers through interactive AI assistance and multi-modal analysis tools.
alternatives.pricing: Freemium model with free basic features and premium subscriptions
alternatives.bestFor: Students and researchers who need help understanding complex scientific papers and accelerating literature review.
keyFeatures: Interactive AI explanations of paper content
pros: Interactive AI explanations are particularly helpful
Multiple tools integrated in one platform
cons: Primarily focused on comprehension rather than discovery
Limited to academic/scientific content
Premium features required for advanced usage
alternatives.whySwitch: Choose SciSpace over Glean if you need help understanding complex scientific papers rather than searching workplace documents, or if you require interactive AI explanations and PDF analysis tools for academic research.

alternatives.name: You.com
alternatives.tagline: AI-powered search engine with privacy and generative features
alternatives.description: You.com is an AI-powered search engine and conversational assistant that combines traditional web search with generative AI capabilities, providing summarized, source-cited answers while generating text and code through conversational interaction. It targets general users, students, and professionals seeking efficient information discovery with a privacy-first approach, multimodal AI integration, and customizable 'apps' within the search interface. Unlike Glean's enterprise workplace focus, You.com serves as a general-purpose AI search engine for public information with strong privacy protections and generative capabilities beyond simple retrieval.
alternatives.pricing: Freemium model with free basic search and paid premium features
alternatives.bestFor: General users, students, and professionals seeking AI-enhanced web search with privacy protections and generative capabilities.
pros: Strong privacy protections compared to competitors
Good balance of traditional and AI search
cons: Not designed for enterprise/internal document search
Limited to publicly available information
Less specialized for specific domains like research
alternatives.whySwitch: Choose You.com over Glean if you need a general-purpose AI search engine for public information with strong privacy protections and generative capabilities, rather than an enterprise workplace search solution.

alternatives.name: Vectara
alternatives.tagline: Fully-managed neural search and RAG platform API
alternatives.description: Vectara is a neural search and retrieval platform that provides developers with a fully-managed API for building conversational search and Retrieval-Augmented Generation applications through an end-to-end system handling document ingestion, embedding, retrieval, and grounded generation. It uniquely focuses on 'grounded generation' to minimize hallucinations by ensuring all AI responses are directly supported by retrieved source data, eliminating the need to manage separate vector databases and LLMs. Unlike Glean's complete enterprise platform, Vectara offers an API-first approach for developers building custom search and RAG applications with managed infrastructure and strong grounding guarantees.
alternatives.pricing: Freemium model with free tier and usage-based paid plans
alternatives.bestFor: Developers building conversational search and RAG applications who want managed infrastructure with strong grounding guarantees.
pros: Good developer experience with clear API
cons: Less control over individual components
Vendor lock-in with managed service
Cost can scale with usage
alternatives.whySwitch: Choose Vectara over Glean if you're a developer building custom search/RAG applications and want a fully-managed API service that handles the entire pipeline from ingestion to grounded generation, minimizing infrastructure management complexity.

howToChoose.title: How to Choose the Right Glean AI Search Alternative

factors.name: Primary Use Case
factors.description: Determine whether you need enterprise workplace search, academic research tools, vector database infrastructure, or general web search. Glean excels at enterprise workplace search, but alternatives specialize in different domains: Semantic Scholar, Consensus, Elicit, and SciSpace for academic research; Milvus, Annoy, and Qdrant for vector infrastructure; Elastic for hybrid enterprise search; You.com for general web search; and Vectara for managed RAG applications.

factors.name: Technical Expertise
factors.description: Assess your team's technical capabilities. Complete platforms like Glean, Elastic, and Vectara require less AI/ML expertise, while infrastructure components like Milvus, Qdrant, and Annoy require significant engineering resources for integration and maintenance. Academic tools like Semantic Scholar and Consensus offer user-friendly interfaces for non-technical researchers.

factors.name: Budget and Pricing Model
factors.description: Consider both initial and long-term costs. Glean's enterprise pricing may be prohibitive for smaller organizations, while open-source options like Milvus and Annoy have no licensing costs but require engineering investment. Freemium models from Consensus, Elicit, SciSpace, You.com, and Vectara offer lower entry points, while Elastic and Qdrant offer both open-source and commercial options.

factors.name: Deployment Requirements
factors.description: Evaluate whether you need cloud-managed services, self-hosted solutions, or hybrid approaches. Glean, Vectara, and managed versions of Elastic and Qdrant offer cloud services, while Milvus, Annoy, and self-hosted Elastic/Qdrant provide more control but require infrastructure management. Academic tools like Semantic Scholar are exclusively cloud-based.

verdict:
The best Glean AI Search alternative depends entirely on your specific needs and use case. For enterprises needing comprehensive workplace search with deep application integration and access governance, Glean remains a strong choice, though Elastic Semantic Search offers compelling competition with its mature ecosystem and hybrid search capabilities.

For academic and research applications, the landscape offers specialized tools that outperform Glean's general enterprise approach. Semantic Scholar stands out as the best free option for scientific literature discovery, while Consensus excels at evidence-based answers, Elicit automates literature review workflows, and SciSpace helps understand complex papers. Researchers should choose based on whether they prioritize discovery (Semantic Scholar), synthesis (Consensus), workflow automation (Elicit), or comprehension (SciSpace).

Developers building custom AI applications have several infrastructure-focused alternatives. Milvus offers the most scalable open-source vector database for massive datasets, Qdrant provides high-performance Rust-based vector operations with filtering, Annoy delivers efficient ANN search for static data, and Vectara simplifies RAG development with fully-managed grounded generation. Choose Milvus for maximum scalability, Qdrant for performance and filtering, Annoy for memory efficiency with static data, or Vectara to minimize infrastructure management.

For general users seeking AI-enhanced web search with privacy, You.com offers a balanced approach combining traditional and generative search. Ultimately, the right choice aligns with your primary use case, technical capabilities, budget constraints, and deployment preferences in the rapidly evolving AI search landscape.

faqs.question: Is Elastic Semantic Search better than Glean AI Search?
faqs.answer: Elastic Semantic Search isn't necessarily 'better' but serves different needs. It's superior if you're already using the Elastic ecosystem or need hybrid search combining traditional BM25 with vector search. Glean may be better for enterprises wanting a complete, opinionated workplace search solution with deep application integration out of the box. Elastic offers more flexibility and customization but requires more configuration, while Glean provides a more turnkey enterprise solution.

faqs.question: What is the cheapest alternative to Glean AI Search?
faqs.answer: The cheapest alternatives are the completely free options: Semantic Scholar for academic research and the open-source versions of Milvus and Annoy for vector search infrastructure. However, 'cheapest' depends on total cost of ownershipâ€”open-source tools require engineering resources for deployment and maintenance. For managed services with free tiers, Consensus, Elicit, SciSpace, You.com, and Vectara offer free usage limits that may suffice for individual or small team use.

faqs.question: What is the best free alternative to Glean AI Search?
faqs.answer: The best free alternative depends on your use case: Semantic Scholar for academic research (completely free with no limits), Milvus for vector database infrastructure (open-source), or You.com for general AI web search (freemium). For enterprise workplace search specifically, there's no direct free alternative to Glean's comprehensive platform, though Elasticsearch has a free basic tier that can be extended with open-source vector search plugins.
